parade.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a public celebration when musical bands, brightly decorated vehicles etc move down the street
parade.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a military ceremony in which soldiers stand or march together so that important people can examine them
parade.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a line of people moving along so that other people can watch them
parade.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a series of people, events etc that seems to never end
parade.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: She had a constant parade of young men coming to visit her.
parade.translation[0].definitions[4].def: a street with a row of small shops
parade.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to walk or march together to celebrate or protest about something
parade.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The marchers paraded peacefully through the capital.
parade.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if you parade your skills, knowledge, possessions etc, you show them publicly in order to make people admire you
parade.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Young athletes will get a chance to parade their skills.
parade.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to walk around, especially in a way that shows that you want people to notice and admire you
parade.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: A trio of girls in extremely tight shorts paraded up and down.
parade.translation[1].definitions[3].def: if prisoners are paraded on television or through the streets, they are shown to the public, in order to prove that the people holding them are important or powerful
parade.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: The prisoners were paraded in front of the TV cameras.
parade.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to proudly show something or someone to other people, because you want to look impressive to them
parade.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: war medals paraded for public admiration
parade.translation[1].definitions[5].def: if soldiers parade, or if an officer parades them, they march together so that an important person can watch them
